lecture_analysis.lecture_title: Vapor-compression refrigeration cycle and performance analysis (R-134a example)
lecture_analysis.lecture_summary: The lecture reviews the four-step vapor-compression refrigeration cycle using a T–s diagram and a system schematic, then works a numerical example for R-134a serving a 2‑ton refrigeration load. It explains the physical nature of each process (isentropic compression, constant-pressure heat rejection in the condenser, isenthalpic expansion through a throttle, and constant-pressure heat absorption in the evaporator) and demonstrates how to obtain state properties from saturated tables, determine refrigerant mass flow, compute compressor power, evaluate coefficient of performance, and estimate entropy generation in the compressor and throttle.
core_topics: Mass flow and compressor power calculations
learning_objectives: explain the four principal processes of the vapor-compression refrigeration cycle
interpret cycle states and paths on a temperature-entropy diagram
use saturated refrigerant property data to determine state properties and vapor quality
calculate refrigerant mass flow required for a specified cooling capacity
compute compressor work and required power accounting for isentropic efficiency
determine the system coefficient of performance
estimate entropy generation in compressor and expansion devices
assumed_prerequisites: familiarity with property tables for refrigerants
concepts of enthalpy, entropy, and phase quality

derivations.derivation_title: Vapor-compression refrigeration cycle: mass flow, compressor work, COP and entropy generation
derivations.derivation_stub: Determine \(\dot m\), compressor power \(\dot W\), COP and entropy generation for a 2-ton R-134a refrigeration system with saturated vapor leaving evaporator at -12°C and saturated liquid at condenser at 10 bar; compressor isentropic efficiency 90%.
steps: Cycle state relations and assumptions (from slides): 1→2 is isentropic compression (ideal), 2→3 constant-pressure heat rejection (condenser), 3→4 constant enthalpy (throttle), 4→1 constant-pressure heat addition (evaporator). Notation: h_i = specific enthalpy at state i, s_i = specific entropy at state i.
Heat extracted at evaporator (given cooling capacity): ``$$\dot Q_c = 2\ \text{ton} = 7\ \text{kW}$$`` (used as positive cooling effect).
Mass flow from evaporator energy balance: ``$$\dot Q_c = \dot m\,(h_1 - h_4) \quad\Rightarrow\quad \dot m = \dfrac{\dot Q_c}{h_1 - h_4}$$`` (slide shows this and numeric substitution).

Determine state enthalpies/entropies from saturation data (slides show table values / interpolations): at -12°C (saturated vapor) and at 10 bar (saturated liquid). Example values used in notes: ``$$h_1 = 243.3\ \text{kJ/kg}\quad (\text{or shown as saturated vapor enthalpy})$$``; ``$$h_4 = h_3 = 107.32\ \text{kJ/kg}$$`` (saturated liquid enthalpy at condenser conditions after throttling) -- these are the table values used in the handwritten solution.

Compute mass flow (numeric step shown in notes): substitute values into ``$$\dot m = \dfrac{7\ \text{kW}}{h_1 - h_4}$$``. Using the handwritten values yields ``$$\dot m \approx 0.0515\ \text{kg/s}$$`` (boxed in notes).

Compressor isentropic-efficiency relation: ``$$\eta_c = \dfrac{h_{2s} - h_1}{h_2 - h_1}$$`` where \(h_{2s}\) is enthalpy after isentropic compression to condenser pressure and \(h_2\) is actual (real) outlet enthalpy. The slide computes \(h_{2s}\) by using ``$$s_{2s}=s_1$$`` and table interpolation to obtain ``$$h_{2s}\approx 278.47\ \text{kJ/kg}$$`` (handwritten).

Solve for actual compressor outlet enthalpy \(h_2\) using efficiency (numeric shown): ``$$0.90 = \dfrac{278.47 - h_1}{h_2 - h_1} \;\Rightarrow\; h_2 \approx 282.4\ \text{kJ/kg}$$`` (value recorded in notes).

Compressor power (shaft input) from mass flow and enthalpy rise: ``$$\dot W = \dot m\,(h_2 - h_1)$$``. Numeric substitution from notes: ``$$(0.0515)\,(282.4 - 243.3) \approx 2.013\ \text{kW}$$`` (boxed result in slides).
Coefficient of performance (COP) for refrigeration cycle: ``$$\text{COP} = \dfrac{\dot Q_c}{\dot W} = \dfrac{7}{2.013} \approx 3.48$$`` (value shown in notes).

Entropy generation in compressor (as shown): ``$$\dot S_{gen,comp} = \dot m\,(s_2 - s_1)$$`` with numbers from the solution: ``$$(0.0515)\,(0.9525 - 0.93911) \approx 6.9\times10^{-4}\ \text{kW/K}$$`` (handwritten value).

Entropy change across throttle (irreversible, isenthalpic): ``$$\dot S_{gen,throttle} = \dot m\,(s_4 - s_3)$$`` with values used in notes: ``$$(0.0515)\,(0.4182 - 0.39189) \approx 1.35\times10^{-3}\ \text{kW/K}$$``.

Summary of numeric results shown on slides: ``$$\dot m\approx0.0515\ \text{kg/s},\quad \dot W\approx2.013\ \text{kW},\quad \text{COP}\approx3.48,\quad \dot S_{gen,comp}\approx6.9\times10^{-4}\ \text{kW/K}$$``.

Completeness: Derivation in slides is largely complete and logically consistent; missing details are the explicit table lookups and interpolation steps used to obtain saturated property values (e.g. the interpolation producing \(h_{2s}\) and some entropy/table values). The slide shows the numeric results but omits the full interpolation arithmetic for some property values.

derivations.derivation_title: Quality and mixture properties at state after throttling (state 4)
derivations.derivation_stub: Compute vapor quality x at state 4 from enthalpy and obtain mixture entropy s4.
steps: Definition of quality x for a two-phase mixture: ``$$h = (1-x)h_f + x h_g \quad\Rightarrow\quad x = \dfrac{h - h_f}{h_g - h_f}$$``.
Using values in notes at -12°C: ``$$h_f = 35.92\ \text{kJ/kg},\quad h_g = 243.3\ \text{kJ/kg},\quad h = h_4 = 107.32\ \text{kJ/kg}$$``.
Numeric quality (handwritten): ``$$x = \dfrac{107.32 - 35.92}{243.3 - 35.92} \approx 0.344$$`` (shown on page).
Mixture entropy from quality: ``$$s_4 = (1-x)s_f + x s_g$$``. Substituting the slide's table values yields ``$$s_4 \approx 0.4182\ \text{kJ/kg K}$$`` (value shown in notes).

derivations.derivation_title: Isentropic outlet enthalpy determination (h2s) and isentropic compression interpolation
derivations.derivation_stub: Find \(h_{2s}\) by applying \(s_{2s}=s_1\) at condenser pressure (table interpolation).
steps: For isentropic compression to condenser pressure: ``$$s_{2s} = s_1$$`` (use saturation / superheated tables at condenser pressure to find corresponding \(h_{2s}\)).
Handwritten interpolation result shown: ``$$h_{2s} \approx 278.47\ \text{kJ/kg}$$`` (interpolation arithmetic is not fully shown in slides).
This \(h_{2s}\) is then used in isentropic-efficiency relation: ``$$\eta_c = \dfrac{h_{2s}-h_1}{h_2-h_1}$$`` to solve for actual \(h_2\).

conceptual_questions.question: The throttling (expansion) valve in the vapor-compression refrigeration cycle (process 3 → 4) is best described as which thermodynamic process?
conceptual_questions.explanation: A throttling valve produces an adiabatic, highly irreversible expansion in which the specific enthalpy remains essentially constant (h3 = h4). It is not isentropic or isothermal.

conceptual_questions.question: The compressor in the lecture has an isentropic efficiency of 90% (η<1). Compared with an ideal isentropic compressor operating between the same pressures, what is the effect on actual compressor work and on the cycle COP for the same refrigeration load?

options.text: Actual compressor work is less than ideal isentropic work; COP increases.
Actual compressor work equals ideal isentropic work; COP is unchanged.
Actual compressor work is greater than ideal isentropic work; COP decreases for the same cooling load.
Actual compressor work is greater than ideal, but COP increases for the same cooling load.

conceptual_questions.explanation: With η<1 the compressor must supply more work than the ideal isentropic case (h2_actual > h2s), so Ẇ increases. For the same refrigeration capacity Q̇L, higher compressor work reduces COP = Q̇L/Ẇ.

conceptual_questions.question: According to the lecture notes and T–s sketch, which components are the primary sources of entropy generation (irreversibilities) in a practical vapor-compression cycle?

options.text: Only the condenser and evaporator (heat exchangers)
No entropy is generated; the cycle is entirely reversible

conceptual_questions.explanation: In a real cycle the compressor (non‑isentropic compression) and the throttling valve (irreversible adiabatic expansion) generate entropy. Idealized heat exchangers can be treated as reversible transfers, so they are not the primary entropy sources.
